Transportation Subsidy Program (PTSP) 1.32.15

) The Public Transportation Subsidy Program (PTSP) was established to encourage employees to use mass public transportation when commuting to and and from work. The beneﬁts will be limited to the maximum monthly amount, excluded from income under section
) of the Internal Revenue (

) Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) contains policies and proce- dures for the Public Transportation Subsidy Program (PTSP). To provide beneﬁts to enrolled participants to commute from their home to their permanent Post of Duty (POD). (
) Audience: This IRM provides information for PTSP participants, managers, National Treasury Employee Union (NTEU) and employees who need more information concerning the program. (
) Policy Owner: Human Capital Officer and Deputy Human Capital Officer. (
) Program Owner: Associate Director, Ogden Payroll Center and the Public Transportation Subsidy Program Office develops and maintains this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Public Transportation Subsidy Program Office and partment of Transportation. (

) Program Goals: The PTSP program will provide monthly and quarterly beneﬁts to employees to use for commuting to/from work through mass portation, as well as guidance on how to enroll, use beneﬁts, and return beneﬁts when not in use. (

) The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Public Transportation Subsidy Program (PTSP) was established to encourage employees to use mass public tation when commuting to and from work. This action improves air quality, reduces traffic congestion, and conserves energy by reducing the number of single occupancy vehicles on the road. (
) Employees using public transportation to commute to and from work may for transit subsidy beneﬁts under the IRS PTSP. (
) Eligible employees using an authorized public transportation method will receive an employer-provided fare subsidy to apply toward their monthly costs. (
) The IRS will pay the transit beneﬁts from appropriated funding, using guidelines. (
) Transit beneﬁts, up to the maximum monthly amount is excluded from nontaxable monthly limit allowed by law. (

) The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Public Transportation Subsidy Program (PTSP) was established to encourage employees to use mass public tation when commuting to and from work. This action improves air quality, reduces traffic congestion, and conserves energy by reducing the number single occupancy vehicles on the road. (
) Employees using public transportation to commute to and from work may for transit subsidy beneﬁts under the IRS PTSP. (
) Eligible employees using an authorized public transportation method will receive an employer-provided fare subsidy to apply toward their monthly costs. (
) The IRS will pay the transit beneﬁts from appropriated funding, using guidelines. (
) Transit beneﬁts, up to the maximum monthly amount is excluded from nontaxable monthly limit allowed by law. (

) The IRS Fare Media Distributor (FMD) is responsible for: a. Ensuring the successful disbursement of the transit subsidy within geographic area. b. Receiving and distributing transit vouchers in locations where the TRANServe Card isn’t accepted. c. Tracking and maintaining records of distributed fare media using lished procedures. d. Informing participants that their PTSP issues may be forwarded to the Employee Resource Center (ERC). (
) The participants are responsible for: a. Ensuring the New Transit Beneﬁt Application, Rate Change/Address Sma

rip Change Application, the Annual Recertiﬁcation Application, Withdrawal Application are submitted electronically and following up their manager to ensure the timely approval of their form. b. Following program guidance by completing the PTSP Awareness

on Integrated Talent Management (ITM), prior to initial and/or re-enrollment in the program. c. Ensuring the beneﬁt requested and received is the proper amount for approved mode of transportation and vendor in their current The amount of transit subsidy must not exceed the employee’s actual monthly public transportation commuting cost. d. Ensuring proper use of the beneﬁt. It is allowed only for the commute between the participant’s residence and work location. This work can be the permanent POD or a minimum of

-day detail location. It must not be sold or transferred to another individual. e. Ensuring adjustments are made to transit subsidy amounts when are changes to transit vendor/provider, commuting cost, work contact information, manager, or home/work address. f. Ensuring parking expenses are not included as part of the commuting cost. g. Returning the unused transit beneﬁt by using Form
-G, PTSP ticipant Return of Fare Media. h. Returning beneﬁt received in advance, upon separating from the IRS. i. Using the most cost-effective/cost-efficient transit beneﬁt type for your commute. (

) If the above responsibilities are not met, the participant may be suspended, withdrawn and/or billed for discrepancies in beneﬁts usage. • All billing of PTSP beneﬁts for misused/abused funds will originate the Beckley Finance Center (BFC). (

in ITM, and ensuring their participating employees do the same. c. Ensuring that all the Transit Beneﬁt Applications on the TRANServe site for their employees are approved/disapproved within
business days of the participant submission. PTSP applications that are not ap- proved timely by the manager, may result in a disruption of PTSP ben- eﬁts to the employee. (

) The PTSP Staff performs the following reviews: a. Performs a full review of all PTSP applications on the TRANServe Management website. Review b. Random sample audit review to ensure PTSP beneﬁts are used c. DOT Funding Reports: These reports are received monthly and upon quest from the Department of Transportation (DOT). They are to keep IRS abreast of the ﬁnancial status of the PTSP program. d. Review unusual transactions and program fund usage for accuracy proper use of PTSP beneﬁts. e. Report misuse/abuse of PTSP beneﬁts. f. Review TRANServe Card participant activity reports and report misuse/ abuse of PTSP funds for repayment to Beckley Finance Center (BFC). g. Administer Annual Recertiﬁcation to ensure PTSP participants review recertify their PTSP beneﬁts. h. Return of Fare Media: A review is done of all participants instructed to repay the government because of improper use of fare media. i. Withdrawal Review: A monthly review ensures all separated PTSP pants are removed from the PTSP database.

(07-22-2020) Program Management and Review
Transportation Subsidy Program (PTSP) 1.32.15 page

Recertiﬁcation: Participants are automatically suspended from the program if they fail to complete the PTSP Annual Recertiﬁcation tion within the required timeframe. Return of Fare Media: Participants must reimburse the check or money order, for improper use of fare media. Withdrawal: A PTSP staff member will remove separated PTSP pants if they are still in the PTSP database. All TRANServe applications will be reviewed for accuracy. Internal audits may be performed to ensure compliance with the contained in this IRM.

In this IRM, the terms below have the following meanings: a. Carpool - An arrangement between people to make a regular journey a single vehicle, typically with each person taking turns driving. b. Cash Reimbursement - An electronic payment deposited to a partici- pant’s bank account of record to reimburse transit expenses when the transit pass is not readily available. c. Commuter Highway Vehicle/Vanpool - A privately owned highway vehicle that seats at least six adults and one driver and uses
% of mileage to transport to and from work. On trips for this purpose, the number of riders must be at least

% of the adult seating capability, including the driver. d. Detail-Temporary assignment of an employee to a different position for speciﬁed period, with the employee returning to regular duties at the of the timeframe. This includes positions at equal, higher, or lower grades. e. Distribution Site - An IRS site where participants can pick up their transit subsidy from a Fare Media Distributor (FMD). f. Fare Media Distributor (FMD) - Individual responsible for receiving and distributing transit vouchers in locations where the TRANServe Card accepted. The FMD also tracks and maintains records of distributed fare media using established procedures. g. Local Transit Authority - An area vendor that provides transportation. h. Manager of Record - The manager of record is the participant’s direct manager or another manager, given temporary access by the direct manager to review and approve applications. i. Non-Temporary Work Location - A location where employment is tically expected to last more than one year, or there is no realistic expectation that it will last for one year or less, regardless of whether it actually exceeds a year. j. Post of Duty (POD) - A place where an employee regularly performs his her duties. k. Public Transportation - Transportation provided in a mass transit or commuter highway vehicle. Acceptable modes of public transportation are: bus, ferry, subway, train, and vanpool. l. Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) - A computer generated alpha numeric string that provides a unique identiﬁer for each IRS employee, eliminating the need for social security number identiﬁcation. SEID are found on the Discovery Directory or in Outlook. m. Subsidized Parking Space - A space speciﬁcally assigned to an employee and paid for by the IRS.
Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures
n. Time
Sensitive Fare Media
A fare payment for use within a speciﬁed timeframe, e.g., monthly subsidy. o. TRANServe Card

A card that provides transit beneﬁts electronically. primary goal of the TRANServe Card is to use a single fare media system that offers enhanced internal controls to preserve the transit by deterring waste, fraud, and abuse. p. Transit Pass/Voucher
A non

cash instrument that is either accepted the local transit authority as fare payment or exchanged for an form of payment. It is tax free and issued in advance. Vouchers are in areas that do not accept the TRANServe Card. q. UBER/LYFT
Is a car for service, not mass transportation, therefore, PTSP beneﬁt may not be used for UBER, LYFT or any pay for service transportation. r. Unlimited Transit Pass
A media that allows public transit passengers take either a certain number of pre
purchased trips or unlimited trips a ﬁxed time period, such as an unlimited monthly pass.

-days or more, and the use of the unlimited transit subsidy to perform ″in and around″ local travel within the city limits (or area covered by the issued unlimited transit subsidy). (
) To be eligible to receive an IRS PTSP transit beneﬁt, employees must use mass public transportation to commute between their residence and their permanent POD or detail location of
days or more. (

) The transit beneﬁt is equal to the participant’s actual monthly commuting up to the maximum nontaxable monthly amount allowed by law, regardless the number of days the public transportation is used. View Publication Employer’s Tax Guide to Fringe Beneﬁts for the maximum amount. (
) To remain eligible in the program, PTSP participants must submit a PTSP certiﬁcation annually to certify their actual commuting cost. (
) In the event of a furlough or temporary shutdown participants should not purchase a monthly pass, they should only purchase a weekly pass or daily tickets. (
) Policy - Parameter of an eligible commute: a. A commute is regular travel back and forth between the employee’s of residence and official duty station during a

-hour period. A place residence will usually be the employee’s primary home, but may also include a place the employee stays regularly. b. It requires that there be no immediate overnight stay between the and work at a location away from the employee’s originating place of residence. c. The complete round-trip between home and work is one that could sonably be expected to occur on a regular basis, even if it does not, fact, occur every weekday. d. A commute need not occur every day; it may occur as infrequently as one time per period in accordance with the employee’s approved work and telework schedule. e. A commute is not reasonable if the whole monthly transit beneﬁt be needed to cover a single one-way trip. f. A commute must take place on official business day, deﬁned as through Friday unless otherwise deﬁned by your office or applicable lective Bargaining Agreement. Internal Revenue Manual
IRS/NTEU Memorandum of Understanding, dated May 5, 2003, discusses the channeling of customer service requests to the Employee Resource Center.
(4) In the event of a furlough or temporary shutdown participants should not purchase a monthly pass, they should only purchase a weekly pass or
- Parameter of an eligible commute: a. A commute is regular travel back and forth between the employee’s of residence and official duty station during a

-hour period. A place of residence will usually be the employee’s primary home, but may also include a place the employee stays regularly. b. It requires that there be no immediate overnight stay between the home and work at a location away from the employee’s originating place of residence. c. The complete round-trip between home and work is one that could rea- sonably be expected to occur on a regular basis, even if it does not, in fact, occur every weekday. d. A commute need not occur every day; it may occur as infrequently as one time per period in accordance with the employee’s approved regular work and telework schedule. e. A commute is not reasonable if the whole monthly transit beneﬁt would be needed to cover a single one-way trip. f. A commute must take place on official business day, deﬁned as Monday through Friday unless otherwise deﬁned by your office or applicable Col- lective Bargaining Agreement.
Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures
Participants are not entitled to beneﬁts during the time when they are:

a. On official business travel, including City-to-City travel where per diem is being paid and/or Local travel is used for in and around travel; case related meeting, NTEU and any other interoffice/site visits. b. On a full day of leave or working an Alternated Work Schedule (AWS) and are out on their regularly scheduled day off. c. Teleworking for a full day at home. d. On jury duty. e. Using a government-owned vehicle to commute to work. f. Using an IRS-subsidized parking space or IRS-assigned parking permit. g. Using a carpool or personal vehicle to commute to and/or from work on day when you are unable to use mass transportation. h. In non-pay status (Furlough, Extended Leave or Leave Without Pay). i. Exiting the program or leaving the Service. j. On a detail less than
days.
modes of public transportation are: bus, ferry (walk-on only), train, and vanpool who meet program requirements.
a. Any highway vehicle with a seating capacity of at least six adults, not including the driver. b. At least
% of the mileage is for transporting employees between their residence and their permanent POD, non-temporary work location, or detail location. c. The number of employees transported is at least
% of the adult seating capacity of such vehicle, not including the driver. If the van seating capacity is six passengers, the van must operate at
% capacity on all commutes with at least three passengers on board at all times, plus the driver, after all riders have been picked up.
Transportation Subsidy Program (PTSP) 1.32.15
Vanpool participants who have the TRANServe Card must use the card for vanpool payments. The vanpool driver must setup a Merchant Account with their bank to accept payments from the TRANServe Card.
for vanpool payments. The vanpool driver must setup a Merchant Account with their bank to accept payments from the TRANServe (
) Parking expenses, whether at a commuter lot or at/or near the workplace, not recoverable and not considered a transit cost under PTSP. (
) An IRS-assigned parking permit that is non-subsidized. (
) Bicycles, scooters and other available green modes of transportation offered by other vendors are not reimbursable. (
) UBER, LYFT, and other Taxi or on demand type car services are not autho- rized modes of transportation. (

) There are three types of subsidy payments for PTSP participants. a. The TRANServe Card b. Transit voucher are available only for locations that do not accept the TRANServe Card. c. Cash Reimbursement on a quarterly basis for vendors who only cash. (

) The type of beneﬁt distributed to the participant depends on the local transit authority’s acceptance of the transit beneﬁt. a. TRANServe Cards are funded one month prior to be used for the following months transit cost. For example, the TRANServe Card is funded in January, the funds on the card are to be used for February’s transit cost. b. The transit voucher is mailed out quarterly to the FMD. c. The Cash reimbursement beneﬁt is equal to the participant’s actual monthly commuting cost, up to the monthly maximum allowed which is excluded from income by law. View Publication

-B, Employer’s Tax Guide to Fringe Beneﬁts for the maximum amount. Cash are provided quarterly after incurring veriﬁed out-of-pocket commuting costs. Cash reimbursements are deposited in the participants Fund Transfer (EFT) account provided by payroll. (
) Transit beneﬁt cannot be: a. Exchanged for cash. b. Transferred from one employee to another. c. Given, loaned, or sold to others. (
) Transit beneﬁt cannot be used: a. To travel to other offices in the area. b. To commute home for non-work days. c. For case related travel.
Parking expenses, whether at a commuter lot or at/or near the workplace, are not recoverable and not considered a transit cost under PTSP.
There are three types of subsidy payments for PTSP participants.
a. The TRANServe Card b. Transit voucher are available only for locations that do not accept the TRANServe Card. c. Cash Reimbursement on a quarterly basis for vendors who only accept cash.
The type of beneﬁt distributed to the participant depends on the local transit authority’s acceptance of the transit beneﬁt.

TRANServe Cards are funded one month prior to be used for the following months transit cost. For example, the TRANServe Card is funded in January, the funds on the card are to be used for February’s transit cost. The transit voucher is mailed out quarterly to the FMD. The Cash reimbursement beneﬁt is equal to the participant’s actual monthly commuting cost, up to the monthly maximum allowed which is excluded from income by law. View Publication

-B, Employer’s Tax Guide to Fringe Beneﬁts for the maximum amount. Cash are provided quarterly after incurring veriﬁed out-of-pocket commuting costs. Cash reimbursements are deposited in the participants Electronic Fund Transfer (EFT) account provided by payroll.
Servicewide Travel Policies and Procedures
) The IRS PTSP transit subsidy beneﬁt is equal to the participant’s actual monthly commuting cost. The maximum transit subsidy amount is by Congress each calendar year. View Publication
-B, Employer’s Tax (Applies Only to Fringe Beneﬁts, for the maximum amount. Participants Who are (

) Participants receiving an advance of the transit subsidy must estimate their Quarterly commuting costs for the upcoming quarter to ensure the appropriate beneﬁt Vouchers) amount is received at the quarterly distribution. (
) Participants are not entitled to beneﬁts for the days they do not use public transportation to commute to and from the assigned workplace. As a result, beneﬁts should be adjusted accordingly. (
) Ideally, estimates should be as accurate as possible to avoid any beneﬁt payment or underpayment. (
) If the beneﬁt was overestimated, the balance must be returned. There are three ways to return excess transit subsidy: a. Return unused transit passes with Form

-G, PTSP Return of Media, to the PTSP Analyst listed on the form. b. Request less transit subsidy at the next distribution. c. Send a personal check or money order payable to Internal Revenue Service. The payment should be sent to the PTSP Analyst listed on
-G. A Document Transmittal Form
should be attached. The subject matter should be addressed as: “To Reimburse the IRS Account for Public Transportation Subsidy.” (
) IRS employees were transitioned to the TRANServe website in February of

All new and/or current participants are required to complete all actions Website related to their PTSP beneﬁts through the TRANServe website. To complete action on the TRANServe website participants must be a registered user valid IRS e-mail address. (
) The TRANServe website is accessible through the IRS network, personal puter, tablet or smartphone with and internet connection. (

) All PTSP actions require the approval of both the participant’s manager of record, PTSP Office Administrator, and the DOT. The participants manager record must be registered on the TRANServe website, in order for the pants to select them as the ﬁrst level approver. Managers have
business days to review and approve or disapprove requests. It’s the participants re- sponsibility to ensure their manager is taking timely action. (

) All TRANServe applications have a comments section for participants to include important information regarding their beneﬁt. For example, vanpool riders must list the name of the driver and all other passengers in the comments section. Or, if you need to have your TRANServe Card mailed to different address other than the ﬁeld requiring your physical home address, enter it in the comments section. (
) All participants must have a SEID number and valid @irs.gov e-mail to enroll in PTSP. Process (
) All new participants must conﬁrm completion of the PTSP Awareness
in ITM prior to submitting an enrollment with the TRANServe website. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

-G. A Document Transmittal Form

All new and/or current participants are required to complete all related to their PTSP beneﬁts through the TRANServe website. To action on the TRANServe website participants must be a registered user valid IRS e-mail address. (
) The TRANServe website is accessible through the IRS network, personal puter, tablet or smartphone with and internet connection. (

) All PTSP actions require the approval of both the participant’s manager of record, PTSP Office Administrator, and the DOT. The participants manager record must be registered on the TRANServe website, in order for the pants to select them as the ﬁrst level approver. Managers have
business days to review and approve or disapprove requests. It’s the participants re- sponsibility to ensure their manager is taking timely action. (

) All TRANServe applications have a comments section for participants to include important information regarding their beneﬁt. For example, vanpool riders must list the name of the driver and all other passengers in the comments section. Or, if you need to have your TRANServe Card mailed to different address other than the ﬁeld requiring your physical home address, enter it in the comments section. (
) All participants must have a SEID number and valid @irs.gov e-mail to enroll in PTSP. (
) All new participants must conﬁrm completion of the PTSP Awareness
in ITM prior to submitting an enrollment with the TRANServe
The TRANServe website is accessible through the IRS network, personal com- puter, tablet or smartphone with and internet connection.
All new participants must conﬁrm completion of the PTSP Awareness Brieﬁng, 19239 in ITM prior to submitting an enrollment with the TRANServe website.

) To apply for PTSP beneﬁts, participants must be registered on the website to complete their new transit application on the TRANServe website. The applicant’s manager of record must approve the new transit beneﬁt cation on the TRANServe website. Once the employee submits their applica- tion, the manager of record will receive an automatic e-mail form the TRANServe Administrator notifying them that there is an application awaiting approval. The effective date for beneﬁts is the date the manager approves accurate and approved application on the TRANServe website. (
) The application is routed the PTSP Administrative Office for approval. Once approved by the PTSP Administrative Office, the application is sent to DOT processing (
) TRANServe applications are processed by DOT within two (
) business (
) Retroactive subsidies, prior to the effective date, are not authorized. (
) If PTSP funding is not available at the time of the effective date, the may review the guidelines on submitting a PTSP cash reimbursement. (
) If the applicant’s POD uses/distributes vouchers, the applicant should check with the POC to ﬁnd out if their subsidy is available. (

) All IRS employees in the vanpool, including the alternate, are eligible to transit beneﬁts and must follow the same enrollment process on the TRAN- Serve website. The effective date for beneﬁts, is the date the manager ap- proves an accurate and approved application on the TRANServe website. (

) If the vanpool is not being operated by an IRS employee, each vanpool designate an IRS employee as the coordinator, who will be responsible for ensuring that the minimum requirements are met monthly. If there is only IRS employee in the vanpool, they will automatically be considered the IRS coordinator. (
) Vanpool drivers must set up a merchant bank account with their banks. This needed to retrieve the funds from the TRANServe Card. Vanpool receive their transit beneﬁt via the TRANServe Card. (

) Vanpool charges must reﬂect reasonable costs, and rates charged must be same for all passengers. Rates may be reduced or waived for the primary driver. Operating expenses for lease, fuel, or tolls qualify for the beneﬁt; maintenance and cleaning do not qualify. (
) If the participant’s monthly expenses are less than the maximum, only the actual monthly amount spent is authorized for subsidy. (
) Participants may only collect transit beneﬁts when actively riding in the vanpool. Vanpool riders may not use the transit beneﬁt to hold a seat in the vanpool in excess of
working days per month, while on annual or sick leave. (
) Participants choosing to commute by vanpool must pay the out-of-pocket to hold a seat in a vanpool in cases of extended absences (in excess of
working days per month) or days absent from the vanpool due to part-time telework schedules.

zation for Third Party Pick-up, must be completely ﬁlled out and signed by participant. Participants can only pick up the transit beneﬁt at their assigned POD. The FMD and the PTSP Office does not maintain an inventory of transit vouchers. The transit beneﬁt is funded and/or distributed in advance. a. TRANServe Cards are funded on the

th of the month for the month. b. Transit vouchers are mailed to the FMD the month before the quarter. c. Transit vouchers are only available for those areas that do not accept TRANServe Card. TRANServe Cards (original and replacements) will be mailed to the partici- pant’s home address as stated on their TRANServe application. If the address is listed as the participant’s POD location, the TRANServe Card be delivered directly to the participant by the mailroom. When picking up vouchers, participants must: a. Present their IRS badge for identiﬁcation. b. Sign and date Form

-F, PTSP Signature Sheet for Up-front Monthly/Quarterly Distribution, indicating receipt and acceptance of transit voucher. c. Verify the transit voucher amount collected is correct for the quarter. Participants must safeguard their TRANServe Card and/or transit voucher becomes their property and responsibility upon receipt. a. To avoid damage to the TRANServe Card, keep magnets away from magnetic strip. Do not staple, fold, or mutilate the transit voucher. b. The transit voucher with the oldest date must be used ﬁrst, preventing expired subsidy. If your TRANServe Card is lost, stolen or damaged you must notify US Customer Service to initiate the replacement process at

or for the hearing impaired. A replacement card will be issued, and the your unused available credit will transfer to the new TRANServe Card. Transit vouchers: a. Cannot be replaced or refunded if lost or stolen. b. If damaged or expired, contact the local transit authority, as they accept it. If the transit voucher isn’t accepted by the transit authority, please return it using Form
-G, PTSP Participant Return of Fare

) Cash reimbursements are only available when an employee is enrolled in PTSP with an accurate and approved enrollment application. oint Site for reimbursement of actual expenses incurred the previous quarter. Employees are not reimbursed from their Enter on (EOD) date. Retroactive subsidies, prior to the effective date, are not authorized. (

Servicewide Travel Policies and (

) PTSP Participants are required to recertify their PTSP beneﬁts annually by submitting an electronic recertiﬁcation through the TRANServe website. Annual Recertiﬁcation is based on your enrollment or last recertiﬁcation (
) Participants will receive an e-mail notiﬁcation informing them of the expiration date of their PTSP recertiﬁcation and the requirements to submit new recertiﬁcation timely. (
) Provisions must be made for participants by their manager of record who do not have access to a computer. (

) If a participant fails to complete their PTSP Annual Recertiﬁcation (i.e., a complete PTSP Annual Recertiﬁcation includes the certiﬁcation of the partici- pant, managerial approval, and PTSP Administrator approval), they will be withdrawn from the program. The withdrawn individual can re-enroll in the program again at any time. Cash reimbursements are not authorized for any out of pocket expenses due to failure to recertify timely. (

) The PTSP Administrative Office will review all PTSP Annual Recertiﬁcations accuracy and return (i.e., disapprove) any recertiﬁcations with; inaccurate mation, overstated travel cost (i.e., not the most cost-effective method of transportation) and potential inappropriate use of the program. (
) Managers must approve or disapprove, the Annual PTSP Recertiﬁcation
business days. Unapproved recertiﬁcations are not authorized for a cash reimbursement. It is the participants responsibility to ensure their is approved. (
) Employees who participate in PTSP and who are separating from the must complete the withdrawal request and have their manager approve the request timely within

business days on the TRANServe website prior to and/or leaving the Service. If the employee is not able to or has already left the vice, it is the manager’s responsibility to request that they be withdrawn by submitting and OS Ge
ervices ticket for PTSP Questions and Answers. (

) Employees who participate in PTSP who are separating from the Service, return or destroy their TRANServe Card, return transit vouchers or any pro- rated portion of beneﬁt received in advance using Form
-G, PTSP Participant Return of Fare Media to the PTSP Office. (

) Employees who participate in PTSP and are furloughed, placed on extended leave, or Non-Work Status (NWS) are automatically withdrawn and must recertify their PTSP beneﬁts upon return to service in order for beneﬁts to restored. (

) Employees who have separated from the Service may be subject to a review of their beneﬁt usage to ensure no funds were used after leaving the Service. Any misused funds may be subject to collection from BFC. (
) Participants who no longer want to be enrolled in the program must submit withdrawal request through the TRANServe website. from the (
) Participants who do not have access to an IRS computer can use the steps to withdraw: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Any beneﬁts loaded to a local transit card (ex. Clipper, Breeze, Sma
rip, Ventra Keycard, etc.) must be returned by check or money order to the IRS. The check/money order must be made out to the Internal Revenue Service, along with a completed Form

-G, PTSP Return of Fare Media. The and check/money order should be mailed to the PTSP Office. Local transit cards should not be returned as they are not a form of repayment for funds, only a check or money order for their balance may be returned. (
) Participants who have not used their PTSP beneﬁts for a minimum of six months will be automatically withdrawn from the system by DOT. (
) Form
- D - PTSP Cash Reimbursement Certiﬁcation - This form may only be utilized when the Cash Reimbursement Shar
oint website is able. Any forms submitted while the Cash Reimbursement Shar

oint is available will not be accepted. The form is submitted by participants at end of the quarter in those instances when the transit beneﬁt is not or available. Cash reimbursements are not authorized for participants who not use the funds from the TRANServe Card or failed to complete their recertiﬁcation of beneﬁts timely. Any approved cash reimbursement forms have an electronic payment sent to their current EFT information. (
) Form
- E - PTSP Authorization for Third Party Pick-Up - The form is prepared and signed by the participant and given to the designated authorizing them to pick up their transit subsidy on their behalf. (
) Form

-F - PTSP Signature Sheet for Up-Front Monthly/Quarterly tion - The FMD will present this form to participants at the transit beneﬁt distribution. Participants sign and date the form indicating receipt and tance of the transit voucher. (
) Form

-G - PTSP Participant Return of Fare Media - The form is submitted when an employee withdraws from the program, separates from Service, or has expired or damaged transit subsidy. Participants should not write void or destroy the transit subsidy. The form is also used if the has received more transit subsidy than entitled. The participant should send the form along with a check or money order to the PTSP Office. (
) Form
- W - PTSP Transit Expense Worksheet - A worksheet used to assist participants in calculating their monthly commuting costs accurately.

Use a personal computer, tablet or smartphone to log into the TRANServe website to submit a Withdrawal request. Contact the ERC to have an OS Ge
ervices ticket opened for PTSP Questions & Assistance. Request their manager open an OS Ge
ervices ticket for PTSP tions & Assistance.

Form 11664 - D - PTSP Cash Reimbursement Certiﬁcation - This form may only be utilized when the Cash Reimbursement SharePoint website is unavail- able. Any forms submitted while the Cash Reimbursement SharePoint website is available will not be accepted. The form is submitted by participants at the end of the quarter in those instances when the transit beneﬁt is not accepted or available. Cash reimbursements are not authorized for participants who did not use the funds from the TRANServe Card or failed to complete their annual recertiﬁcation of beneﬁts timely. Any approved cash reimbursement forms will have an electronic payment sent to their current EFT information.

Form 11664-G - PTSP Participant Return of Fare Media - The form is submitted when an employee withdraws from the program, separates from the Service, or has expired or damaged transit subsidy. Participants should not write void or destroy the transit subsidy. The form is also used if the participant has received more transit subsidy than entitled. The participant should send the form along with a check or money order to the PTSP Office.
Form 11664- W - PTSP Transit Expense Worksheet - A worksheet used to assist participants in calculating their monthly commuting costs accurately.
Servicewide Travel Policies and (
) Participants using Washington Metro Area Transit Authority’s (WMATA) rail and/or bus system are required to purchase a Sma
rip card. You can purchase one by mail, online or at Metro’s sales offices and area transit Sma
rip cards must be registered with Metro at the time of purchase by telephone at
or on-line at www.smartrip.com. (
) Sma
rip cards must be registered to match the name in Discovery on the IRS Source. (
) The Sma
rip card must be registered prior to submitting or including the Sma
rip card number on a TRANServe application. The TRANServe tion only requires number from the Sma
rip card. Failure to include any numeric characters will result in a disapproved application from the DOT may cause a delay in beneﬁts. (
) Information pertaining to the use or functionality of the Sma
rip card may found on the WMATA.com website. (
) Unused Smar
eneﬁts are returned to DOT at the end of each month. (
) Lost, stolen, damaged or malfunctioning Sma
rip cards that have been tered, can be replaced without losing any of the fare value by contacting at
The PTSP Office cannot replace the funds or assist the replacement of the Sma
rip card. Metro will transfer the balance to the new Sma
rip card and deduct the cost of a new card from your personal purse and mail it to you. Ensure the new card is registered and then and Address/Sma
rip card change through the TRANServe website to the Sma
rip card number to match the new number. (
) Participants should not use their Sma
rip cards with the PTSP transit for personal use at any time. (
) Senior citizens (
and older) and persons with disabilities must have a WMATA Senior/Disabled ID card in order to receive the reduced fare under the senior/disabled Sma
rip guidelines. (
) Employees on detail assignments may qualify for the IRS PTSP program. a. Detail must be at least
-days or more in order to be eligible. Any for less than
-days is not eligible for PTSP beneﬁts. b. Employees who are already enrolled in PTSP and are detailed for than
-days may update their current beneﬁts to reﬂect any changes the beneﬁt amount needed. If the detail is less than
-days and the to commute remains the same no change is needed. If the cost of commute increases for a detail of less than
days, the difference in cost is the employee’s responsibility and not eligible for additional funding. c. Employees who are not already enrolled in PTSP may enroll if the is for
-days or more. If the detail is less than
-days, the employee may not enroll in PTSP. (

) Participants in PTSP are not authorized to use the PTSP beneﬁt for local and-around travel (i.e., case related meetings, site visits, union stewards., Pass etc.). Local travel must be claimed via the Concu
ov program as a local travel authorization/voucher.

) A monthly or unlimited type pass may not be the most mode of transportation for regular commute between residence and official POD based on work schedule. Local travel should not be considered when purchasing PTSP beneﬁts and/or as part of your monthly commute. ing these types of passes for use outside of commuting between residence and official POD is not authorized. (
) Participants cannot use PTSP beneﬁts and ﬁle a local travel authorization/ voucher for the same expenses. (

) In partnership with DOT, TRANServe is a program to deliver transit beneﬁts participants through a branded federal credit card, called the TRANServe The TRANServe Card provides a green, cost-efficient, all electronic method employees to receive their monthly transit beneﬁt. (
) TRANServe Cards are accepted for the majority of transit providers the United States. (
) The TRANServe Card must be activated upon receipt by contacting US at the customer service number on the back of the card (
for hearing impaired). The Interactive Voice Response (IVR) system guide the cardholder through the automated processed. (
) Participants cannot receive a cash reimbursement for unused funds on the TRANServe Card. (
) The TRANServe Card must be returned to the participants manager of when furloughed, on approved extended leave, separating from the Service withdrawing. (
) Management is responsible for the safekeeping of the card during this time and must return the TRANServe Card to the furloughed employee upon ﬁrst day back to work status. (
) Participant is responsible for recertifying their PTSP beneﬁts through the TRANServe website upon return to work in order for beneﬁts to be (

) Each time you use your TRANServe Card you certify: a. I am employed by the federal government. b. I am eligible for a public transportation fare beneﬁt. c. I will only use the transit beneﬁt for my daily commute to and from my residence and official POD. d. I will not use the beneﬁt for local visits to other offices. e. I will not give, sell or transfer my transit beneﬁt to anyone else. f. I will not use the government-provided transit beneﬁt in excess of the statutory limit. g. I will not include parking fees in the computation of the daily, weekly monthly commuting cost. (

) Participants who move to a new POD within IRS and currently have a TRANServe Card should keep the card and take it to their new POD. The is still active and loaded with funds which can be used towards their new commuting cost. Upon arrival at the new POD, participants must complete update through the TRANServe website and include pertinent information the comments section. Internal Revenue Manual

) Participants who transfer to another agency must withdraw from the and either return the TRANServe Card using Form
-G PTSP Return of Fare Media or destroy the card. If the participant does not from the IRS PTSP, they will not be able to enroll with another agency. (
) The TRANServe Cards are mailed by the contracted bank to the home address on the participants PTSP application unless otherwise directed by participant. (

) The PTSP Administrative Office encourages seniors to take advantage of senior and/or Medicare cardholder discounts. Check with your local transit authority to see if they offer senior discounts. Eligible participants can their PTSP commuting cost by completing a rate change on the website. (

) PTSP participants who telework regularly should abide by the following: a. Ensure the transit beneﬁts received match the number of days in the office. Beneﬁts can’t exceed the amount needed. Estimated days per month; Regular Schedule

days per as a frequent teleworker would not generally require a monthly transit pass as it would not be the most cost-effective/cost-efficient. may contact their local transit authority for information and/or on the most cost-effective/cost-efficient type of pass for their b. th of the month for smartcards and TRANServe Cards on the TRANServe website. c. Participants with computer access who need to adjust their cost should submit a rate change on the TRANServe website. The in- structions are:
